results.lead_paragraph: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 2 25 HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a witchcraft school. 2 1 11 HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is menaced when an infamous murderer escapes from prison. 3 3 50 HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for witchcraft. 4 1 TIMELINE, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $26.95.) Using the latest computer technology, a group of historians travels back to 14th-century feudal France. 5 4 3 IRRESISTIBLE FORCES, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) The marriage of a professional couple is strained by their having to live a continent apart. 6 7 2 SAVING FAITH, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $26.95.) A man and a woman get caught in machinations of the F.B.I. involving corrupt forces in Washington. 7 6 7 A WALK TO REMEMBER, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $19.95.) In 1958, a high school senior in North Carolina finds love with the daughter of a Baptist minister. 8 5 5 POP GOES THE WEASEL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) The lives of Alex Cross and his fiancee are imperiled as he pursues a serial killer at large in Washington's diplomatic corps. 9 9 2 HUNTING BADGER, by Tony Hillerman. (HarperCollins, $26.) Two Navajo lawmen search for the truth behind a murder and the F.B.I.'s investigation of it. 10 12 10 HEARTS IN ATLANTIS, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) Five long, interconnected stories about an America haunted by the Vietnam War. 11 8 6 ''O'' IS FOR OUTLAW, by Sue Grafton. (Wood/Holt, $26.) The private eye Kinsey Millhone has to reappraise her youthful values while trying to solve a murder. 12 10 8 PERSONAL INJURIES, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) A crooked lawyer joins forces with an F.B.I. agent who has secrets of her own. 13 11 4 BLUE AT THE MIZZEN, by Patrick O'Brian. (Norton, $24.) The series of historical novels about the British Navy officers Jack Aubrey and Stephen Maturin continues. 14 13 21 TARA ROAD, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $24.95.) Two women -- one from Ireland, one from New England -- exchange houses for the summer. 15 1 PLAINSONG, by Kent Haruf. (Knopf, $24.) A half-dozen members of a high-plains Colorado community learn to contend with the variety of problems that face them. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 3 5 HAVE A NICE DAY! by Mick Foley. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $25.) The autobiography of a professional wrestler known as Mankind. 2 1 9 'TIS, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) An Irish immigrant gets used to life in America: the second volume of a memoir. 3 2 111 TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter recalls his college mentor. 4 4 51 THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War II. 5 6 9 WHEN PRIDE STILL MATTERED, by David Maraniss. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) The life of Vince Lombardi. 6 13 3 *LIFE: Our Century in Pictures, edited by Richard B. Stolley and Tony Chiu. (Bulfinch/Little, Brown, $60.) An album of photographs from Life magazine. 7 11 3 JOHN GLENN: A Memoir, by John Glenn with Nick Taylor. (Bantam, $27.) The former astronaut and United States senator from Ohio tells his life story. 8 14 11 *FAITH OF MY FATHERS, by John McCain with Mark Salter. (Random House, $25.) A family memoir by the United States senator and former P.O.W. 9 12 5 GALILEO'S DAUGHTER, by Dava Sobel. (Walker, $27.) The life and trials of Galileo Galilei, as seen through the letters of his cloistered, illegitimate daughter. 10 5 4 *THE NEW NEW THING, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $25.95.) The story of Jim Clark, a technical and financial pioneer in the computer world. 11 9 46 THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems. 12 8 7 A MAN NAMED DAVE, by Dave Pelzer. (Dutton, $19.95.) The concluding volume of a memoir that began with ''A Child Called 'It' ''and ''The Lost Boy.'' (+) 13 7 7 3ALL THE BEST, GEORGE BUSH, by George Bush. (Drew/Scribner, $30.) The former president's letters, diary entries and memos, with commentary. (+) 14 15 2 AND THE CROWD GOES WILD, by Joe Garner. (Sourcebooks, $49.95.) Memorable sports events recalled in words and photographs and on two CD's. 15 10 3 *RIVER-HORSE, by William Least Heat-Moon. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $26.) The author's journey across America, from New York to Oregon, in a small boat. 16 3 9 *THE CENTURY, by Peter Jennings and Todd Brewster. (Doubleday, $60.) An account of the 20th century, complete with photographs and first-person narratives. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 10 GUINNESS WORLD RECORDS 2000. (Guinness, $25.95.) A profusely illustrated collection of records about subjects as various as sports and technology. 2 2 WHO MOVED MY CHEESE? by Spencer Johnson. (Putnam, $19.95.) How to deal with changes at work and in life in general. (+) 3 2 70 SUGAR BUSTERS! by H. Leighton Steward et al. (Ballantine, $22.) A diet designed for losing weight, increasing energy and combating disease. (+) 4 3 4 DON'T SWEAT THE SMALL STUFF IN LOVE, by Richard Carlson and Kristine Carlson. (Hyperion, $15.95.) Ways to maintain good personal relationships. Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Nov. 20, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) DISGRACE, by J. M. Coetzee. (Viking, $23.95.) The ''disgrace'' of the title belongs to the central character of this novel (winner of this year's Booker Prize in Britain), a Cape Town intellectual whose sexual sin, later visited on his daughter, is made to reflect the old guilt of white privilege. DOUBLE DOWN: Reflections on Gambling and Loss, by Frederick Barthelme and Steven Barthelme. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) Two brothers, both writers of distinguished fiction, tell how they lost more than $300,000 and managed to be indicted for cheating as well. EDWARD M. KENNEDY: A Biography, by Adam Clymer. (Morrow, $27.50.) A thorough, careful account of the growth of a senator who has earned more respect than seemed likely in his youth; by the chief Washington correspondent of The Times. HOMESICKNESS, by Murray Bail. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, paper, $14.) An Australian novel that cogitates on the dubious pleasures of mass tourism as a group of 13 follows a senseless itinerary through surreal and baffling museums. THE LONG HOME, by William Gay. (MacMurray & Beck, $24.95.) This first novelist fears no theme, however large; it's good versus evil in Faulkner territory, and good succeeds only when it's better armed than evil and willing to exert violence. LOSING NELSON, by Barry Unsworth. (Doubleday, $23.95.) A provocative, absorbing novel whose mad hero hides from his own life by his elaborate identification with Admiral Nelson, a folly he understands well enough to labor at the same time to destroy it. THE NEW SWEET STYLE, by Vassily Aksyonov. (Random House, $29.95.) A luscious Russian novel with a love story at its heart, surrounded by picaresque events in America and demanding, the author insists, frequent help from the reader. SILENT STARS, by Jeanine Basinger. (Knopf, $35.) A film historian argues that many of the stars of the silents, especially Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks, wielded talent and cultural scope that have been forgotten as the films themselves were forgotten, lost or just unseen. THE WALKING TOUR, by Kathryn Davis. (Houghton Mifflin, $23.) A brilliantly dexterous novel that manages to contain a 20th-century murder mystery, told in a post-global-disaster future by one victim's daughter. (The other victim was somehow responsible for the disaster.) WALTER BENJAMIN AT THE DAIRY QUEEN: Reflections at Sixty and Beyond, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $21.) A peculiar book, part memoir, part tour de force, part commonplace book, in which the author of ''Lonesome Dove'' regrets what he thinks is his failure to subvert fallacies about the Old West.

results.snippet: Adrift above the Earth, the eye to the universe is closed. But if all goes according to plan, the Hubble Space Telescope, a window through which humans have viewed the edges of space for almost a decade, will soon be reawakened by the nudging, gloved...
results.lead_paragraph: Adrift above the Earth, the eye to the universe is closed. But if all goes according to plan, the Hubble Space Telescope, a window through which humans have viewed the edges of space for almost a decade, will soon be reawakened by the nudging, gloved hands of astronauts replacing and repairing the failed inner works that forced it into hibernation. This weekend, as NASA still struggles to understand the silence from Mars where the Mars Polar Lander was scheduled to touch down on Friday, the space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to blast off on a mission to restore the observatory. The telescope has been shut down since Nov. 13, when its precision pointing system failed and the observatory went dormant.

results.abstract: Paul Theroux Op-Ed article holds desire of traveler to disconnect and disappear is harder to fulfill in connected world; notes his youthful travels could not be repeated today; drawing (M)
results.snippet: Travel seems to produce a peculiar sort of licensed bore, the very worst of whom rejoice in the theme, ''When the going was good.'' The point is usually that when they traveled (''Oh, heavens, this was years ago . . .''), it was absolutely marvelous,...
results.lead_paragraph: Travel seems to produce a peculiar sort of licensed bore, the very worst of whom rejoice in the theme, ''When the going was good.'' The point is usually that when they traveled (''Oh, heavens, this was years ago . . .''), it was absolutely marvelous, and too bad you weren't traveling then. But this is largely boastful bunk, and misses the point, for travel is the opposite of a holiday. It is about enlightenment and, at its best, is a form of disappearance. As recently as 40 years ago, a person could evaporate by traveling; even a trip to Europe involved a sort of obscurity. A trip to Africa or South America was a vanishing into silence. In a connected world, it is not so easy to get lost, and this is probably to our detriment.

results.abstract: Curt Newport discusses underwater expedition he led to recover Liberty Bell 7 space capsule; photo; effort is recounted in Discovery Channel television documentary (M)

headline.main: Rescued From the Deep, 38 Years Later

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: IN SEARCH OF LIBERTY BELL 7 (TV PROGRAM)

results.snippet: ''Back when I started thinking about it, I didn't know what ocean it was in,'' said Curt Newport, an underwater recovery expert. ''I thought it might be the Pacific.'' Fourteen years of research taught him otherwise. To be precise, the Mercury space...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Back when I started thinking about it, I didn't know what ocean it was in,'' said Curt Newport, an underwater recovery expert. ''I thought it might be the Pacific.'' Fourteen years of research taught him otherwise. To be precise, the Mercury space capsule he sought, not much larger than a refrigerator, was in the Atlantic, 300 miles off the Florida coast. To be even more precise, it lay in the three-by-eight-mile patch of water plotted by Mr. Newport. To be absolutely precise, it was exactly the sonar ping he thought it was, 15,600 feet down. An object as prominent as the second vehicle an American rode into space ordinarily might be found front and center in an air and space museum. As recounted in the documentary ''In Search of Liberty Bell 7,'' tonight at 9 on the Discovery Channel, this particular piece of history spent 38 years on the bottom, waiting for the technology that could reach it at that depth.

results.abstract: Investigators document almost 3,000 medical mistakes and mishaps in less than two years at veterans hospitals around the country; more than 700 patients have died in those cases; problems include medication errors, failure of medical devices, abuse of patients, errors in blood transfusion, surgery on the wrong body part or the wrong patient, improper insertion of catheters or feeding tubes, and a variety of 'therapeutic misadventures'; report, written by Dr James E McManus, medical inspector for Veterans Affairs Department, suggests what could be expected if all hospitals had to report their errors, as recommended recently by National Academy of Science (M)

headline.main: REPORT OUTLINES MEDICAL ERRORS IN V.A. HOSPITALS

results.snippet: Federal investigators have documented almost 3,000 medical mistakes and mishaps in less than two years at veterans hospitals around the country, and more than 700 patients have died in those cases, the Department of Veterans Affairs says in a new...
results.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators have documented almost 3,000 medical mistakes and mishaps in less than two years at veterans hospitals around the country, and more than 700 patients have died in those cases, the Department of Veterans Affairs says in a new report. The accidents and deaths occurred from June 1997 to December 1998, in the first 19 months of a new policy that requires employees to report medical errors and ''adverse events.'' Since then, the department has been getting such reports at a rate of more than 200 a month.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery astronauts snag Hubble Space Telescope and return it to cargo bay to begin critical repairs (M)

headline.main: Gotcha! Space Shuttle Crew Captures Broken Telescope

results.snippet: After a spirited chase across the sky, the space shuttle Discovery grabbed the Hubble Space Telescope with its robot arm today, retrieving the observatory to begin a critical repair mission.    The space shuttle, which had been chasing Hubble since...
results.lead_paragraph: After a spirited chase across the sky, the space shuttle Discovery grabbed the Hubble Space Telescope with its robot arm today, retrieving the observatory to begin a critical repair mission. The space shuttle, which had been chasing Hubble since being launched on Sunday, spent the day closing in on the observatory from below through a series of rocket firings.

results.abstract: Discovery astronauts Steven L Smith and John M Grunsfeld take space walk to repair dormant Hubble Space Telescope, replacing faulty gyroscopes that forced observatory into hibernation last month; task described (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Crew Starts Repairs On Telescope

results.snippet: A pair of spacewalking astronauts today began the intricate process of repairing the dormant Hubble Space Telescope, replacing the faulty gyroscopes that forced the observatory into hibernation last month.    With one astronaut standing on the end of...
results.lead_paragraph: A pair of spacewalking astronauts today began the intricate process of repairing the dormant Hubble Space Telescope, replacing the faulty gyroscopes that forced the observatory into hibernation last month. With one astronaut standing on the end of the shuttle Discovery's 50-foot robot arm and the other hooked to the telescope, the men used power wrenches and other tools to laboriously pull out three boxes that each contained two of Hubble's six stabilizing gyroscopes and replace them with new units.

headline.main: On Second Outing, Astronauts Continue Upgrade of Telescope

results.snippet: The Hubble Space Telescope got smarter and better able to point at distant astronomical targets today as spacewalking astronauts replaced two major pieces of the observatory's gear.    On the second spacewalk of the shuttle Discovery's Hubble repair...
results.lead_paragraph: The Hubble Space Telescope got smarter and better able to point at distant astronomical targets today as spacewalking astronauts replaced two major pieces of the observatory's gear. On the second spacewalk of the shuttle Discovery's Hubble repair mission, the astronauts, C. Michael Foale and Claude Nicollier, swapped out the observatory's central computer and one of its fine guidance sensors, a precision pointing device.

results.abstract: Sarah Boxer article on masks, both primitive and modern, in light of Stephen Kaplin's article in Drama Review on masks and other 'performing objects,' an exhibition of masks at St Louis Art Museum, and the masks and instruments designed by the artist Krzysztof Wodiczko to help immigrants make their way into strange new civilizations; photos (M)

headline.main: When a Mask Reveals Far More Than It Hides

results.snippet: Once upon a time masks belonged to anthropology. They were strange objects made of wood, shells, feathers and bells that primitives wore for coming-of-age rituals, funerary rites, rain dances, fertility festivals and seasonal get-togethers. As...
results.lead_paragraph: Once upon a time masks belonged to anthropology. They were strange objects made of wood, shells, feathers and bells that primitives wore for coming-of-age rituals, funerary rites, rain dances, fertility festivals and seasonal get-togethers. As recently as 1975, Claude Levi-Strauss wrote a study about the masks of the Northwest Coast Indians, ''The Way of the Masks,'' showing their relationship to the Indians' kinship patterns. Well, those days are gone. There are no more primitives. Or rather, we are all primitives. Modern people wear hockey masks, gas masks and surgical masks. You could say that modern masks are just for protection. You could also say that hockey, war and surgery are rituals and that these masks reveal something about the relationships of the people who wear them.

Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 3 114 TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door. 2 5 2 THE GREATEST GENERATION SPEAKS: Letters and Reflections, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $19.95.) What the people who fought in World War II confided in letters to the author. 3 2 54 THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War II. 4 3 8 HAVE A NICE DAY! by Mick Foley. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $25.) The autobiography of a professional wrestler known as Mankind. 5 6 6 LIFE: Our Century in Pictures, edited by Richard B. Stolley and Tony Chiu. (Bulfinch/Little, Brown, $60.) Photographs from Life magazine, with essays. 6 10 3 ESPN SPORTSCENTURY, edited by Michael MacCambridge. (ESPN/Hyperion, $40.) Essays and photographs about American sports in the 20th century. 7 4 12 'TIS, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) An Irish immigrant gets used to life in America. 8 8 5 AND THE CROWD GOES WILD, by Joe Garner. (Sourcebooks, $49.95.) Sports events in words and photographs and on two CD's narrated by Bob Costas. 9 9 12 WHEN PRIDE STILL MATTERED, by David Maraniss. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) The life of Vince Lombardi. 10 7 42 THE CENTURY, by Peter Jennings and Todd Brewster. (Doubleday, $60.) An illustrated account of the 1900's. 11 5 JOHN GLENN: A Memoir, by John Glenn with Nick Taylor. (Bantam, $27.) The former astronaut and United States senator from Ohio tells his life story. 12 1 *HELL TO PAY, by Barbara Olson. (Regnery, $27.95.) A critical account of the life and career of Hillary Rodham Clinton by a former federal prosecutor. 13 14 14 *FAITH OF MY FATHERS, by John McCain with Mark Salter. (Random House, $25.) A family memoir by the United States senator and former P.O.W. (+) 14 11 8 GALILEO'S DAUGHTER, by Dava Sobel. (Walker, $27.) The life and trials of Galileo Galilei, as seen through the letters of his cloistered, illegitimate daughter. 15 13 49 THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems. 16 15 10 *ALL THE BEST, GEORGE BUSH, by George Bush. (Drew/Scribner, $30.) The former president's letters, diary entries and memos, with commentary. (+) Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 13 GUINNESS WORLD RECORDS 2000. (Guinness, $25.95.) A profusely illustrated collection of records about subjects as various as sports and technology. 2 2 18 BODY FOR LIFE, by Bill Phillips with Michael D'Orso. (HarperCollins, $25.) Ways to improve one's body and one's life. (+) 3 4 2 EVERY DAY'S A PARTY, by Emeril Lagasse with Marcelle Bienvenu and Felicia Willett. (Morrow, $26.) Recipes for cooking Louisiana style. 4 3 5 WHO MOVED MY CHEESE? by Spencer Johnson. (Putnam, $19.95.) How to deal with changes at work and in life in general. (+) Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Dec. 11, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) DISGRACE, by J. M. Coetzee. (Viking, $23.95.) The ''disgrace'' of the title belongs to the central character of this novel (winner of this year's Booker Prize in Britain), a Cape Town intellectual whose sexual sin, later visited on his daughter, is made to reflect the old guilt of white privilege. DOUBLE DOWN: Reflections on Gambling and Loss, by Frederick Barthelme and Steven Barthelme. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) Two brothers, both writers of distinguished fiction, tell how they managed to lose more than $300,000. EMPIRE EXPRESS: Building the First Transcontinental Railroad, by David Haward Bain. (Viking, $34.95.) An authoritative, engaging history of the gigantic enterprise that linked the coasts of America in 1869, and of the robber barons and immigrant workers who did it. THE GOODLIFE, by Keith Scribner. (Riverhead, $23.95.) A novel that ponders why crime stories so fascinate us while telling a hair-raising tale of a kidnap gone wrong, using five narrative points of view without ever getting confused or woozy. MAILER: A Biography, by Mary V. Dearborn. (Houghton Mifflin, $30.) Norman Mailer carefully examined from without (no interviews) by a writer who appreciates the equal importance of his life and his work in understanding America in the second half of the 20th century. OSBERT SITWELL, by Philip Ziegler. (Knopf, $30.) An elegant, expertly written life of Sir Osbert Sitwell, an ineffable aristocrat with a temporary literary reputation and a permanent conviction that he, his sister Edith and his brother Sacheverell were made of superior clay. REMBRANDT'S EYES, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $50.) A huge, digressive, learned, personal, often fascinating book defending Rembrandt's genius, as if it needed defending. SIAM: Or, The Woman Who Shot a Man, by Lily Tuck. (Sewanee Writers' Series/Overlook, $23.95.) An intelligent, sparely written, politically preoccupied novel in which a young American wife in Thailand during the Vietnam War suffers first confusion, then obsession, then tragedy. THE SORCERER'S APPRENTICE: Picasso, Provence, and Douglas Cooper, by John Richardson. (Knopf, $26.95.) Picasso's biographer takes time out to give an account of his own early life and his relationship with the rich and prickly art historian and collector Douglas Cooper. WALTER BENJAMIN AT THE DAIRY QUEEN: Reflections at Sixty and Beyond, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $21.) A peculiar book, part memoir, part tour de force, part commonplace book, in which the author of ''Lonesome Dove'' regrets what he thinks is his failure to subvert fallacies about the Old West.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery astronauts prepare to return to Earth after eight-day mission to repair Hubble Space Telescope; NASA declares mission success; shuttle will land at Cape Canaveral on December 27 (S)

headline.main: Repairs Done, Shuttle Crew Makes Plans For Landing

results.snippet: Crew members of the space shuttle Discovery packed up their tools today and prepared to return home after an eight-day mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope.    Discovery is to land at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida at 5:21 p.m. on...
results.lead_paragraph: Crew members of the space shuttle Discovery packed up their tools today and prepared to return home after an eight-day mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope. Discovery is to land at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida at 5:21 p.m. on Monday.

results.abstract: Astronauts test collapsible private crew quarters designed by team of NASA architects for International Space Station; architect Garrett Finney comments; photos (M)

headline.main: Putting a Room of One's Own in Orbit

results.snippet: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT once said, ''A house is not going anywhere, if we can help it.'' On the cusp of the year 2000, it is hard to imagine what would shock him more: that houses are going into orbit, or that architects are helping design them....
results.lead_paragraph: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT once said, ''A house is not going anywhere, if we can help it.'' On the cusp of the year 2000, it is hard to imagine what would shock him more: that houses are going into orbit, or that architects are helping design them. Certainly, Wright would be wary of the required synthetic materials and the enormous artistic restraint placed on designers.
